I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) transfers knowledge and technical 
capacity on the methods used to analyze debt and assess debt sustainability in Asia and the 
Pacific. There are two components to the TA. The first focuses on data analysis and research and 
assesses debt sustainability across the developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). In-depth thematic, empirical, and country studies, which will involve 
international experts and practitioners, will identify the main aspects of debt vulnerability in the 
region and discuss remedial policy options. The studies will be published as a collection and 
disclosed to stakeholders and the public. The second component enhances the capacity to 
assess debt sustainability among DMCs. Training activities will be held for DMC officials, followed 
by support and tutoring to ensure that recipients can apply the knowledge. Capacity building will 
be  tailored  to  local  circumstances  and  demands––which  the  TA  will  identify  with  DMC 
stakeholders, ADB regional departments, and international partner organizations––and will stay 
within the limits of the TA budget.  
 
2.  The TA is included in the work program and budget framework of ADB’s Economic 
Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) and is aligned with Strategy 2030’s 
sixth operational priority of strengthening governance and institutional capacity.1 The TA will help 
strengthen the analytical capacity of public institutions regarding debt sustainability, which aligns 
with Strategy 2030’s focus on strong institutional capacity as the basis for country development.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The world’s debt is approaching 250% of global gross domestic product. The mounting 
debt  ratios  worldwide  have  caused  policy  makers  to  focus  on  debt  sustainability  and  the 
challenges a global debt overhang entails. The complacency of markets notwithstanding, the risks 
associated with heightened debt are a crucial global economic policy issue involving advanced, 
emerging, and developing economies alike. The international community voiced these concerns 
also at the April 2019 meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, 
and the May 2019 annual meeting of ADB in Fiji.  
 
4.  Across DMCs, the average ratio of total debt to gross domestic product has grown beyond 
200%, or two-thirds in the past decade alone, mainly because of surging private debt.3 Unusually 
low interest rates and easy monetary policies fueled credit booms to support investment and 
growth and international capitals’ search for higher yields. This caused debt ratios to balloon, 
including in some of Asia’s most vibrant emerging economies. Fortunately, most countries in the 
region continue to enjoy a large growth–interest rate differential that is keeping public debt ratios 
in check. Also, compared to when the Asian crisis struck in the late 1990s, reserves are generally 
higher, external exposure is less, and the macroeconomic footing is more sound today. 
 
5.  While  the  outlook  appears  to  be  benign,  many  economies  remain  susceptible  to 
exogenous price shocks; intensifying risks of disasters, capital flight, reserves erosion; or have 
debt profiles complicated by currency or term mismatches. Sources of vulnerability abound across

the region, especially among the lower-income and less diversified economies, several of which 
the IMF and World Bank classified this past year as being at high risk of debt distress, a 
downgrade from earlier assessments.  
 
6.  Additional challenges facing the region have emerged. For example, contingent liabilities 
in relation to highly leveraged households and non-financial corporations may result from shocks 
such as a mortgage crisis or a sharp hike in effective interest rates. In some economies, this could 
constitute a significant systemic risk that may end up weighing on public finances and debt. 
Further challenges stem from a shift in countries’ borrowing portfolios towards new creditors, 
sovereign and commercial, and a rising incidence of highly collateralized debt contracts and other 
financial arrangements that affect a country’s debt sustainability yet remain undisclosed to the 
public and the broader community of creditors.  
 
7.  Against this shifting backdrop, policy makers often find themselves ill-equipped with the 
analytical  tools  and  know-how  necessary  to  effectively  assess  risk  in  the  context  of  debt 
management and policy surveillance. Limited capacity to assess debt sustainability leaves credit 
risks unaccounted for, undermines debt management, and heightens the probability of adverse 
developments and debt crises in DMCs. The TA aims to counter this risk by narrowing the 
knowledge gap through the targeted transfer of analytical capabilities where they are needed 
most. It will do so by supporting and complementing the work of the World Bank and IMF, 
especially in fostering DMCs’ capacity to adopt and apply the latest advances in the debt 
sustainability frameworks for market access countries and low-income countries, and through 
research targeting areas of heightened vulnerability in the region. 
 
8.  The TA will build on previous work in the field of debt sustainability analysis accomplished 
by ERCD, particularly Regional Technical Assistance 7662 “Sovereign Debt Sustainability in Asia 
and  Pacific”  (concluded  in  December  2012),  and  Small-Scale  Research  and  Development 
Technical Assistance 8893 “Exploring Risk-Based Debt Sustainability Assessment Methods” 
(concluded in May 2017). Through its research and capacity building activities, the TA forms part 
of ADB’s bank-wide approach in support of public debt management, which involves plans for two 
further TA projects within ADB, one providing capacity development in DMCs’ sovereign asset-
liability management, and another supporting debt management in Asian Development Fund 
countries at a high or moderate risk of debt distress. ADB’s TAs in these areas will jointly 
contribute to building capacity for the effective monitoring and managing of public debt and fiscal 
risks, a core element of the Multipronged Approach for addressing emerging debt vulnerabilities 
promoted by the World Bank and IMF. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: DMCs’ debt sustainability improved.4 The TA 
will have the following outcome: DMCs’ capacity to assess debt sustainability strengthened.5  
                                                
4  The TA’s impact is aligned with Strategy 2030’s sixth operational priority of strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity (footnote 1) and its aims to strengthen ADB’s role as a knowledge provider and DMC’s institutional capacity 
in addressing development issues. 
5  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Research outputs on debt sustainability in Asia disseminated. Overview, 
thematic, case, and country studies will characterize debt profiles and sustainability issues in the 
region and discuss the main challenges ahead. These studies will focus on and add value beyond 
standard debt sustainability assessments, e.g., estimating risks in relation to contingent liabilities 
from corporate and household debt.6 The studies will be prepared in collaboration with leading 
scholars and practitioners and will be published by ADB as an edited volume in partnership with 
a reputable publisher. A free electronic version will be disclosed to the public, and a limited 
number of printed copies will be disseminated to key stakeholders.7 The TA will also produce 
journal articles, working papers, blogs, and contributions to ADB’s corporate publications, such 
as the Asia Bond Monitor. To support TA research activities, a broad range of data on DMC public 
and external debt will be collected and updated regularly within the limits of public data availability.  
 
11.  Output  2:  Technical  capacity  building  on  debt  analytics  and  sustainability 
assessment methods delivered. Several DMCs partially lack the analytical tools and capacity 
needed to effectively assess vulnerabilities stemming from factors such as elevated private 
corporate debt, hidden liabilities, or exposure to disasters triggered by natural hazards. Technical 
support to these countries is sporadic and often comes in the form of standardized courses that 
are insufficiently customized to local circumstances and have little impact on local capacity. To fill 
this gap, the TA will transfer crucial skillsets and technical knowledge through a combination of 
custom-tailored training, tutoring, and providing expert consultancy. Recipients from DMC debt 
management offices, the ministry of finance, the central bank, or other government agencies will 
first receive training on the debt sustainability frameworks as developed by the World Bank and 
the IMF and/or other complementary analytical tools. To ensure that DMC government institutions 
will optimally absorb and apply the newly acquired analytical skills, they will also be offered 
support while adapting these frameworks to the specific context of application, including through 
temporary on-site support where feasible. To assure complementarity and alignment of objectives, 
the TA will coordinate with partner institutions operating in the region, such as the IMF–Singapore 
Regional Training Institute. The TA  aims  to  train  at  least  80  officials  in  DMCs—mainly  in 
coordination with debt management offices and involving the budget and planning departments—
that are interested and suitable to participate, in consultation with ADB departments and resident 
missions, as appropriate.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. ERCD’s Office of the Chief Economist and Director General 
(EROD) will be responsible for supervision and management of consultants, procurement, and 
accomplishment of the outputs. For optimal coordination and synergy as “One ADB,” especially

regarding capacity building, EROD will coordinate with ADB’s other departments and resident 
missions and rely on their collaboration and support, as appropriate. In particular, the regional 
departments  will  help  identify  suitable  DMC  recipients  and  facilitate  capacity  building  in 
coordination with country authorities. For possible research collaboration and joint conferences 
and dissemination activities, the TA will also identify and partner with reputable regional or global 
research institutions.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.8 Up to 10 individual international consultants will be engaged for the 
research project to prepare analytical, country, and case studies involving debt analytics in Asia. 
One national consultant will be hired to assist with data collection and analysis. For capacity 
building activities, the TA will engage two or more individual international consultants to support 
on-site activities and one national consultant to coordinate training. ADB will engage experts, 
which could include ADB staff, as resource persons to produce knowledge products and facilitate 
training. Engaging individual consultants will provide more benefits to ADB than engaging a firm 
because the experience and qualifications of individual experts on debt analytics are of crucial 
importance to the implementation of the TA.9 It would also be difficult to find a firm that specializes 
in the field of debt sustainability assessments in Asia.

16.  Knowledge partnerships. Outputs of the TA may require ADB to enter into knowledge 
partnership agreements with international organizations, academic institutions, and/or think tanks 
of intellectual and advisory nature. Any knowledge partnerships entered into will follow the Staff 
Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance 
Operations.10 The partnership agreements will clearly delineate roles and disbursements. 
 
17.  ADB’s procurement. The purchase of information communication technology-related 
equipment, supplies, econometric or statistical programs and/or software, and data subscription 
and/or purchase will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time)  
and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). Where 
applicable,  the  TA  team  will  coordinate  with  ADB’s  Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial 
Management Department and Office of the General Counsel before purchasing datasets and 
signing data use agreements with DMC statistical agencies and third-party database providers. 
The TA team will also consult ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology and Office of 
Administrative Services in relation to the purchase of information communication technology 
hardware and software.11 After the TA is completed, the TA team will dispose of any procured 
equipment in compliance with the project administration instructions on administering grant-
financed TA projects.12 Disbursements under this TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Debt Analytics and Technical Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
